context: <b5_0>The transition from the mandolino to the mandolin<b5_0/> began around <a0_0><b10_0>1744<b10_0/><a0_0/> with the designing of the metal-string mandolin by the Vinaccia family, 3 brass strings and one of gut, using friction tuning pegs on a fingerboard that sat "flush" with the sound table. The mandolin grew in popularity over the next 60 years, <a1_0><b11_0>in the streets where it was used by young men courting and by street musicians, and in the concert hall<b11_0/><a1_0/>. <a2_0><b12_0>After the <b6_0>Napoleonic Wars<b6_0/> of 1815<b12_0/>, however, its popularity began to fall<a2_0/>. The 19th century produced some prominent players, including <a3_0><b13_0>Bartolomeo Bortolazzi of Venice and Pietro Vimercati<b13_0/><a3_0/>. However, professional virtuosity was in decline, and the mandolin music changed as the mandolin became a folk instrument; "the large repertoire of notated instrumental music for the mandolino and the mandoline was completely forgotten". <b7_0>The export market for mandolins<b7_0/> from Italy dried up around <a4_0><b14_0>1815<b14_0/><a4_0/>, and when Carmine de Laurentiis wrote <b8_0>a mandolin method<b8_0/> in 1874, the Music World magazine wrote that the mandolin was "out of date." Salvador Léonardi mentioned this decline in his 1921 book, <b9_0>Méthode pour Banjoline ou Mandoline-Banjo<b9_0/>, saying that the mandolin had been declining in popularity from previous times.
